Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: RUI: Multiple-Antenna Systems in Spatially Distributed Networks with Non-Idealized Assumptions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electromagnetic spectrum is becoming scarce as the usage of wireless communications devices becomes ubiquitous. Current research has shown that by using multiple antennas at each wireless device, significantly higher densities of users can share the electromagnetic spectrum without reducing the performance of individual users. Most existing research in this area however is based on idealized system models that are often unrealistic. This project studies the extent to which the promising performance gains of multi-antenna systems predicted using idealized network models apply to networks models with more realistic assumptions, and is an important bridge between existing theoretical understanding and future practical implementation of a technology that could potentially alleviate the spectral crowding problem significantly.

Most existing research on spatially-distributed wireless networks with multi-antenna nodes is based on idealized models such as uniformly random spatial distribution of users, uncorrelated channels between antennas, and the availability of accurate channel-state-information (CSI); assumptions which often do not hold in practice. The investigator is studying the impact of non-uniform node distributions, channel correlations, and inaccurate CSI on the performance of wireless networks with multi-antenna nodes. Specific questions addressed include 1) What spectral efficiencies can be achieved in such networks? 2) To what extent can increasing the number of antennas per user with user density maintain constant perlink data rates in such networks? 3) What are appropriate models for spatial node distribution, channel correlation, and CSI uncertainty for spatially distributed networks? Answers to these questions help improve existing understanding of the performance benefits of multiple-antenna systems in realistic systems and in particular, their potential to alleviate spectral crowding in practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The explosion in demand for wireless communications has resulted in the crowding of the electromagnetic spectrum. One potential means to help alleviate this problem is by using multiple antennas at user devices. In prior work, multiantenna technology has been shown to potentially substantially increase data communication rates or increase the density of users that can be serviced in a wireless network. These findings were made using idealistic assumptions on the spatial distribution of users, availability of accurate information about  the communications channel at user devices and synchronization between all users in a network. This research program sought to understand the performance that one can expect in wireless networks when the idealized assumptions are not made, thus helping enable the use of multiantenna technology in practical wireless networks, to help alleviate the spectral crowding problem.

 The work focuses on networks with users at correlated positions, channel estimation errors and the effects of timing synchronization errors. Exact expressions for the Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) of a typical link in doubly stochastic networks which include clustered and non-homogenous node distributions were derived. The SINR is a quantity that directly determines data communication rates, and whether or not a wireless link can be established. and the CDF of ths SINR provides a complete characterization of statistical properties of the SINR.

Asymptotic techniques were used to characterize the spectral efficiency in a network with users at correlated positions for a general network model in two journal. The SINR was characterized for multiantenna networks with unsynchronized users in a conference paper. Cellular networks with large numbers of base station antennas were analyzed under varying sets of assumptions (e.g. regular cells, random cells, powercontrol and under channel estimation errors), and asymptotically tight approximations for the statistical distribution of spectral efficiency (b/s/Hz) were derived in three different conference papers.

The intellectual merit in this work lies in the characterization of the performance of multiantenna systems in networks with non-idealized assumptions which help bridge the gap between the highly idealized results that existed in the literature and practical implementation. For instance, the PI and students characterized the performance improvement that one can expect when using multiple antennas in highly clustered networks. While the fact that multiple antennas used for interference mitigation can help improve data rates significantly in highly clustered environments is intuitive, these findings quantify the performance improvement that one can obtain in such networks helping system designers trade off between the increased cost, and increased data rates that result from increased numbers of antennas. Another finding was that, the achievable data rates in many wireless networks with users distributed in spatially correlated positions, a problem that is well recognized to be particularly challenging, approaches that of a network with users at uncorrelated positions as the number of antennas at receivers gets large. Moreover, these findings were obtained through combining random matrix theory which has proven to be an invaluable tool to analyze multiantenna systems, and stochastic geometry which has recently risen to prominence as a mathematical tool to model wireless networks with spatially distributed users.

 

Four undergraduate students, two of whom are women, have worked on this project. One of the students recently completed a graduate program at UC Berkeley two are currently at Stanford University, and another is currently in a graduate program at the Joan & Irwin Jacobs Technion-Cornell Institute....
